This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Telesforo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Nzingo

texts.en:
Nzingo is a married woman with nine children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. 

For over ten years, she has operated a charcoal selling business. In addition she also sells fresh water which contributes to her other source of income. She sells from a shop and door to door to her neighbours and passersby. Nzingo faces a major challenge of competition and seasonality in her business. She hopes to open a poultry business in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu because of its good customer relations.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Vilma Estela

texts.es: Vilma Estela H. A. de 39 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Santa Ana en donde vive junto a su esposo y dos hijos menores de edad. Ella posee una tienda de productos perecederos, la cual esta ubicada en su propia casa. En dicho negocia ella comercializa leche, pan, golosinas y otros productos más. Ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda surtir su negocio, sobre todo con productos los cuales son muy básicos en el hogar. Vilma desea mucho poder mejorar las ventas, ya que es ella quien le brinda la ayuda necesaria a su esposo para poder solventar todos los gastos del hogar, esto debido a que el sueldo de su compañero de vida no da a bastos para todas las necesidad existentes, sobre todo porque como buenos padres, ambos anhelas poder brindarles los estudios universitarios a sus hijos, ya que el mayor de ellos esta por ingresar a la universidad y Vilma y su esposo desean poder a través de los estudios brindarle un mejor futuro.
texts.en: Vilma Estela H. A. is 39 years old.  She lives in Santa Ana department with her husband and two dependent children.  She owns a grocery store which is located in her own home.  In her business she sells milk, bread, candies and other products.  She is requesting a loan with which she can stock her business, particularly with basic household products.  Vilma would like very much to be able to improve her sales since she provides her husband with the necessary help to cover all their household expenses because his wage does not cover all their current needs.  Above all this is the case because, as good parents, they both wish to be able to put their children through university since their eldest is about to enter university and Vilma and her husband would like to be able to provide him with an education which will, in turn, give him a better future.

loans.use: To buy food products and basic household products

loans.name: Bright

texts.en: Bright is a twenty-five-year-old man, very enterprising and determined to take his business to greater heights. He lives in Fort Portal, Uganda and his family dream is to build a permanent house for residence. He has been operating   a butcher shop for the last five years and the business is still profitable. Bright needs the loan to buy cattle to sell as beef in anticipation of increased sales during the festive Christmas season.

loans.use: Buying cattle to sell as beef

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline T. is 26 years old, married to Ken T., and a mother of three- Malton, 8 years, Jeptum, 4 years and Kandagor, 3 years. Caroline supports her family through income she gets from her beauty salon, which allows her to contribute to the family’s total income.  She started the salon two years ago and she earns a monthly profit of 5000 KES. 

Caroline has taken a loan of 50,000 KES and she intends to use the entire amount to purchase a variety of cosmetic products for her beauty salon. She anticipates some profits which she will use to expand her salon.

Her future hopes are for her business to grow to a level that she is able to provide for her family's needs and wants.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy corn to improve her business

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran lives in Kot Radha Kishen. It is a small city located near Kasur Pakistan and famous for its dairy industry. She is 35 years old and lives in a 3 room brick house with her family. She moved here 15 years ago with her family.  She is married to M. H. who is a carpenter by profession and makes furniture. He is excellent in his art and makes beautiful furniture. Due to his quality of work and good designs, people approach him and give him a good number of orders. 

In order to financially support her husband, Sughran does embroidery works. She has a number of clients in her local area and earns good income by completing the orders on time. She has given birth to 2 daughters. Her eldest daughter is studying in 5th grade while the younger one stays at home. 

Sughran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy wood, nails and a furniture polisher  that will enable him to make furniture of different designs for his clients. Sughran is hopeful that an investment will allow her husband to offer a greater variety of furniture to his customers and will enable him to fulfill larger orders on time. 

She is a regular user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit rating and never missed a meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Sughran.

loans.use: To buy wood, nails and a furniture polisher for a furniture making business

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita B. is from the village of Bayo, Iguig, Cagayan. She is 60 years old. Rosita is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her raised animals.

In 2010, Rosita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional livestock to raise & sell in future. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rosita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: María Elena

texts.es: María Elena P. D. T. D. 42 años D. edad, es una señora con muchas ganas D. salir adelante y D. contar una vida mejor para su familia. Ella vive junto a su esposo y tres hijos menores D. edad en el municipio D. Soyapango, en el departamento D. San Salvador. María posee un comedor, en el cual elabora desayunos y almuerzos, los cuales los comercializa con las personas del lugar. Debido a que cuenta con una ubicación muy buena, por el hecho que esta rodeada D. escuelas y fábricas, posee muchos clientes quienes a diario asisten a su negocio a consumir sus platillos. María solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar verduras, arroz, frijoles y maíz, carne, pollo y otros productos más, los cuales son muy necesarios para la elaboración D. comida. Para ella es D. mucha importancia poder mejorar las condiciones D. su negocio, y así vivir mejor junto a su familia.
texts.en:
María Elena P. D. T. is 42 years old.  She is a woman who has a great desire to get ahead and create a better life for her family.  She lives together with her husband and three dependent children in the town of Soyapango, in San Salvador department.  María owns an eatery in which she makes breakfasts and lunches to sell to people in the town.  As she has a very good location which is surrounded by schools and factories, she has many customers who come to her business every day to eat her dishes.

María is requesting a loan which she can use to buy vegetables, rice, beans, corn, meat, chicken and other products which are essential for making her food.  For her, it is very important to be able to improve her business' conditions and thereby live better together with her family.

loans.use: To buy basic grains, vegetables and other products for making her meals

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en: Abdul is a fifty-one-year-old ambitious man with seven children living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is charged with the responsibility of taking care of the family, with a dream of being able to provide a minimal comfortable standard of living to each of his household members. Abdul is both a mechanic and a farmer  and has been working hard in these businesses for twenty-eight years now as they have made him realize incredible results. He needs the loan to pay labor for clearing his farmland and to buy onions seeds for planting.

loans.use: Paying labor for clearing his farmland and buying onions seeds for planting

loans.name: Hedda

texts.en:
Hedda L. is a widow who lives in Purok Pag-asa, Poblacion II, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: a general store, selling frozen foods and a RTW dealer (Natasha, Avon) businesses. She has 5 children and all have families of their own. 

Hedda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Hedda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25000, which she intends to use to purchase more stocks to sell so that she could continue to save up for the future. Hedda L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Nhem N., 56, is married and lives with his wife and three children in the Takeo province. He is a moto-taxi driver, making US$4 of profit a day. His wife raises chickens and grows rice. On average, she makes US$4 per day. This couple also recieves support from three children who work in a garment factory. 

Nhem N. is asking for a loan of US$1200 to purchase a trailer to attach with his motorbike. With a trailer attachment, he will hopefully earn more income to support his family.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer.

loans.name: Akylbek

texts.en:
Akylbek B. is the very attentive father of four children. He applies every effort to give them a prosperous future. He was born in Ak-Bulun  village, where he still lives with his tight-knit family. After graduating from secondary school and serving in the army, he returned home and got a job at a local farm. Akylbek worked as a truck driver for 15 years, but after the breakdown of the Soviet Union, he lost his job. Like many people in this situation, Akylbek decided to start his own business in cattle breeding. 

Using his starting capital of 3500 KGS, he purchased a milk cow, and owing to his persistent and hardworking personality, Akylbek managed to multiply his investments. Currently, his farm has three cows, twenty sheep, three bull calves and three horses.
 
Akylbek plans to use this loan of 60000 KGS to increase the number of cattle for fattening and reselling. With the revenues, he plans to finance his son's wedding and give a good education to the younger children.
  
In the future, Akylbek plans to develop a big farm that he can pass on to his children and future grandchildren.
 
Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. It uses Kiva funding to target especially vulnerable populations. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Seema's Group

texts.en:
Seema G. M. is divorced and has two sons. They live in a small city called Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. Due to poor financial conditions, Seema was unable to educate her children, but she taught them the art of making curtains (used to hang on doors and windows to keep the  sunshine out). 

This has become their family business and they have been able to improve their financial position through this business. They make curtains to supply to different shops in the market and earn a good profit. The specialty of their curtains is that they use different embroidery designs to attract more clients.
 
Seema has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to grow their curtains business. With the loan, they will buy cloth, beads and colored thread in bulk quantity to make curtains in larger quantity to fulfill the orders of their customers.
 
Seema is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who holds a book (called the Asasah Passbook) is Seema.

loans.use: To buy cloth, beads and colored thread to make curtains

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen L. is a married woman who lives in Purok Suyac, Brgy Taba-ao, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a fishing and fish-vending business. Her husband. Feliciano L., is 57 years old and works as a fisherman to earn his living. They have five children who are between 26 to 34 years old and all are married. 

Helen joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Helen has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing PHP 19500, which she intends to use to purchase a pump boat, an outrigger canoe powered by a small engine. She will use the profit from the loan for the future maintenance of her pump boat for fishing. 

Helen L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy a pumpboat

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

She has operated a retail shop for more than two years. Her customers are neighbors and passersby. Saumu faces a major challenge of competition from other retail shop operators in the area. She hopes to expand her retail shop and sell wholesale. 

With the KES 30000 loan, she wants to purchase three boxes of milk, three sacks of sugar, sixty liters of cooking oil and one crate of tomatoes. She decided to join Yehu because it provides sustainable financial services to small-scale entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase three boxes of milk, three sacks of sugar, sixty liters of cooking oil and one crate of tomatoes

loans.name: Chem

texts.en:
Chem C., 31, is married and lives with her husband and one young child in the Takeo province. 

She and her husband sell cow rope. On average, they make US $6 every day. Chem C. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase more cow rope for resale.

loans.use: To buy cow rope for resale.

loans.name: Sun

texts.en: Sun A. is 41 years old and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She is a farmer and also makes cow rope to support her family income. On average, she is able to make about $4 USD profit each day. Her husband purchases gas stoves from a company and resells them around his village. He earns $8 USD per day. Sun A. would like to take out a loan of $1,000 USD for her husband to purchase a few gas stoves for resale.

loans.use: To purchase gas stoves for resale

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is 44 years old and runs a grocery store business in a busy part of Nairobi. Her store attracts a good flow of customers. Monica is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to add stock of omena (young fish), sukuma wiki (kales) and tomatoes, among other products. She is a single mother of two young adults and describes herself as hardworking, happy, honest and trustworthy. In the future, she hopes to be an employer with several business outlets.

loans.use: To add stock of omena (young fish), sukuma wiki (kales) and tomatoes, among other products

loans.name: Em

texts.en: Em S., 36, is a blacksmith in Takeo province. He is married with four children. On average, he is able to make about $6 USD per day. His wife, pictured here, stays at home. Since 2003 she has been raising pigs and makes $4 USD a day. Em S. is asking for a loan of $1,000 USD to purchase blacksmith tools.

loans.use: To purchase blacksmith tools

loans.name: Philip

texts.en: Phillip is a thirty-five-year-old married man, with three children. He is the breadwinner of the family living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He lives in his own house and his family dream is to see all his children have the highest levels of education. He has been in the transport business for the last twelve years as a taxi driver and has found minimal hindrances although his business dream is to have his own car. Phillip needs the loan to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: Paying school fees for the children.

loans.name: Phoung

texts.en: Phoung S., 31, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Takeo province. She raises cows and works in a garment factory, making $3 USD every day. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver and earns, on average, $3 USD per day. Since his current motorbike is too old, Phoung S. is asking for a loan of $500 USD to replace her husband's old and unreliable motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike for her husband

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is 30 years old. He sells clothes in Nairobi for both men and women. He is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase both ladies' and gentlemen's clothes for resale. David is hardworking and plans to open more outlets in the next five years. He is married and a father to two young children.

loans.use: To purchase both men and women's clothing

loans.name: Ses

texts.en: Ses S., 32, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She makes and sells brooms in the local market, earning $1 USD profit each day. Her husband is a blacksmith and makes approximately $4 USD per day. This couple has four children – two are in school and two work in a garment factory. Ses S. is asking for a loan of $800 USD to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work. The motorbike will cost her around $600 USD and with the remaining $200 USD she will raise cows.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children

loans.name: Ma. Victoria Efipani

texts.en:
Ma. Victoria Efipani G. is from the village of Nuesa, Roxas, Isabela. She is 38 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Victoria Efipani owns and operates a specialized retail store selling metal and metal-related products in the local community. Ma. Victoria Efipani has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 4,200 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Ma. Victoria Efipani joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase new equipment and tools to expand the business. Ma. Victoria Efipani is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Soun

texts.en: Soun L., 32, is a professional tailor, making $3 USD each day. She lives in Takeo province. She is married and supports two children who live at home. Her husband, Man Kosal, makes approximately $4 USD a day, running a moto-taxi business. Soun L. would like a loan of $1,000 USD to make a new investment with her sister, selling used phones at the local market.

loans.use: To purchase used phones for resale

loans.name: Phou

texts.en: Phou P., 28, is a motorbike dealer in Takeo province. He purchases and sells used motorbikes and is able to make about US$ 5 in profit every day. His wife is employed in a garment factory and makes US$ 3 per day. This couple has one young child who just started attending school. Phou P. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike for resale.

loans.use: Resell used motorbike

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is a thirty-one-year-old hardworking man, married with three children, living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has a grand dream of educating his children up to tertiary levels and increasing his household income on a daily basis. He deals in brick making and has been in the business for eleven years. From this he has been able to start up a bar and a shop and his dream is to have his own plot of land in the trading center so as to construct a rental house. Emmanuel intends to use the loan to pay labor to make more bricks for sale.

loans.use: Paying labor to make more bricks for sale

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad is a very supportive lady. She has a dairy business. She does this business at her home by getting milk from the buffalo. She sells milk to her nearby areas and generates income for the family. 

She comes from a city named Pakpattan, famous in Pakistan for its agriculture industry. She is a widow and lives in her father’s home. Her father sells a Punjabi food item named "Gool gappay" ( round balls filled with yogurt and spicy sauces) to his customers on a four-wheeled cart  and earns income for the family. Her brother also lives with her and he operates a CD center in the market. He sells different video CDs and DVDs to his clients at reasonable prices. 

Irshad has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her brother’s business. With the loan, he will buy CDs and DVDs in bulk to sell at his CD center. He has been in this business for over 10 years and Irshad is hopeful that an investment will help his business and take it to more profitable position. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy CDs & DVDs for CD center business

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en: Fredrick is 28 years old and in business. He sells auto spare parts in a conducive environment. His main customers are vehicle owners. He is requesting a loan of Kes. 20,000 to buy more motor spare parts for sale. Fredrick is married and a father of two young children. He hopes to establish himself in business and become a prominent businessman with a five-year plan of selling auto spare parts wholesale. He describes himself as honest, GOD-fearing, and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy more auto spare parts for sale

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn D. A. is 38 years old, married and supports her family by operating two business ventures: selling ready-to-wear items and buying and selling slippers. She lives in Purok Kabungahan, Brgy Fabrica, Sagay City, Negros Occidental.
Jenelyn has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1997 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her ready-to-wear and slipper businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 20,000 PHP.
Jenelyn is now borrowing 29,500 PHP to purchase additional supplies for her ready-to-wear business. This will be her 20th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 29,500 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Jenelyn aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure its future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase timber for making cabinets in  his carpentry shop.

loans.name: Phon

texts.en:
Phon N., 26, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She is a garment factory worker and makes US $2 every day, while her husband sells coconuts and makes palm sugar. On average, he earns US $4 of profit a day. This couple has three children.

Phon N. would like to take out a loan of US $1,000 to invest in her husband’s palm sugar business.

loans.use: Buy equipment to make palm sugar and reinvest more.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing and insuring a dairy cow

loans.name: Jonalyn

texts.en: Jonalyn A. is 44 years old, married and supports her family by operating a sari-sari (variety) store. She lives in Sotio Quary, Barangay Rafaela, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her sari-sari store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000. Jonalyn is now borrowing PHP 22,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Jonalyn aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more product to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Voek

texts.en:
Voek V., 28, is married with two young children living at home in Takeo province. She works in a garment factory, typically making US $3.50 each day and her husband works in construction. Her husband typically makes about US $4 each day.

Voek V. learned how to do make up and hair, so now she would like a loan of US $500 to open a hairdressing shop. She will resign from her current work and start a new business very soon.

loans.use: To open a hairdressing shop.

loans.name: Machor

texts.en:
Machor S. is from the village of Bayo, Iguig, Cagayan. She is 21 years old. Machor is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Machor operates a family member's business venture: a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling different kinds of fruits and vegetables in the local community. Machor has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Machor joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Machor is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as capital for raising chickens. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Machor from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and use as capital for raising chickens

loans.name: Lerma

texts.en:
Lerma V. is a married woman who lives in Purok Ipil-ipil, Brgy Bulanon, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  food vending and general store businesses. Her husband Sunny V., who is 39 years old, works as a driver to earn his living.  They have two children who are 8 and 10 years old. 

Lerma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 5 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lerma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 6th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to fund her business operations so that she can continue to save up for the future to sustain their daily needs and to educate their children. Lerma V. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Funds for her business operation

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cooking fat, wheat flour, sugar and charcoal

loans.name: Mussarat Muhammad Aslam Group

texts.en:
Mussarat is a very talented lady who owns and operates an embroidering business from home. She receives orders from different boutiques and shops and completes them in a timely manner to earn money for her family. In this photo, Mussarat is raising her hand. 

Mussarat he lives in Pakpattan, which is a small city in Pakistan that is known for its agriculture industry. For the past 15 years, Mussarat has lived in a two-room brick house with her family. She is married to M. A. whose business is hand making sofas that he sells for a very good price. They have three daughters and one son, all of whom are enrolled in a local school and getting an education. 

Mussarat has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy foam, cloth, and nails to make furniture to sell. Mussarat is hopeful that her husband, who has been doing this business for the past 10 years, will be able to make his business more successful and profitable with this loan. 

Mussarat is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. She has proven herself to be a responsible client who pays her installments on time and never misses meetings.

loans.use: To buy foam, cloth, and nails to make sofas

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena I. is 52-years old, married, and supports her family by running a general store and vegetable vending business. She lives in Purok Kalubihan, Brgy Bulanon, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1996 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8000. 

Lorena is now borrowing PHP 19500 so that she can use the money as additional capital. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Lorena aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Choeurn

texts.en: Choeurn L. is 28 years old and sells vegetables in the Takeo province. Her business has been around for about four years and she makes US$2 every day. Her husband is a construction foreman and earns US$3 per day. Selling vegetables has been a difficult business, as there is high inflation and weather conditions that have not been conducive to a good growing season. Choeurn L. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase construction tools for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools.

loans.name: Nom

texts.en: Nom K. is 27, married, and has two young children.  She and her husband live in the Takeo province. To earn a living, she has been working as a garment factory worker and is able to make about $2 every day. Her husband sells coconuts and earns $3 per day. Currently, her husband walks his trailer selling coconuts.  Nom K. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase a motorbike to attach to the trailer for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: John

texts.en: John K. M. is married and he is a father of three children.  He has been in business since 2006 selling VCDs, DVDs and CDs. The business is strategically located on a highway and he employs one person. He is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase a duplicator and accessories.  He hopes to acquire a piece of land in the future with a five-year plan of relocating to the town center and distributing DVDs, VCDs, and CDs wholesale.

loans.use: To purchase a duplicator and accessories

loans.name: Luna

texts.en:
Luna E. is married and lives in Purok Bombills, Brgy Old Sagay, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by running two business: selling ready-to-wear clothes and raising pigs. Her husband, Basilio Endona Jr., is 39 years old and works in construction. They have a child who is five years old. Luna joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she wanted to improve her family's life. With the help of six previous loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Luna has been slowly lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. She has applied for a seventh loan, for PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to stock her clothing store. Her long-term goals are to expand her business and repair her house. Luna E. is a Dungganon (or honorable) woman who is following an honest path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian M. M. is 33 years old, single and has no children. She makes a living selling porridge in different areas in Mombasa, a city on Kenya's coastal region which is well-known for its many tourist attractions and white-sand beaches. She has been in this business for the last three years and enjoys serving the local population. Her business is profitable, although she must move around constantly to find new customers. But she is determined to work very hard and has applied for a Kiva loan for Kes 80,000 to buy more grain to mill and sell as cereals.  She hopes to grow her business and become a supplier of cereals to a larger group of customers. She describes herself as welcoming and friendly.

loans.use: to buy flour to mill and sell as cereals

loans.name: Som

texts.en: Som M., 67, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. The couple earns about $1.50 a day by running a farm, and receives help from its three children, two of whom work in garment factories while the third works in construction. Som M. has applied for a loan for US $700 to buy a motorbike that her children will use to commute to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Hadayat's Group

texts.en: Hadayat lives in Pakpattan, a small city in Pakistan that is known for sugar production. She lives in a small, two-room house with her family in a part of town known as Talhi Wala Muhallah. She is 49 years old and married to G. M.. She supports her family by making clothes. She has vast experience in making designer clothing and has a good number of clients in nearby areas. She is very helpful and supportive person, and is applying for a loan which her brother-in-law will use to expand his business of selling construction supplies, including cement, bricks and sand. He has been in this business for many years and is well-known in his area. Hadayat's son works with him, and is helping his uncle to expand the business. This will be Hadayat's third loan from Asasah, where she has established a good a good credit score by never missing a payment.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies

loans.name: Chhuon

texts.en: Chhuon C. is 27 years old, married to 25-year old Pourn Phat (who we see here) and lives in Phnom Penh City.  She works in a garment factory, where she earns a fixed income to help support her family. Pourn Phat makes a living by selling fruit in a busy market in town, and earns about $3 a day.  Chhuon C. wants to increase her husband's income by expanding his business, and has applied for this loan to allow him to buy more fruit to sell to his customers. (Chhuon C. was not available the day this photo was taken, so we see her husband instead.)

loans.use: To buy a large quantify of fruits to sell.

loans.name: Maribelle

texts.en:
Maribelle D. is 31 years old and married. She supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store and a tricycle operator business. She lives in Purok Maabi-abihon, Brgy Balintawak, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her sari-sari (general) store and tricycle operator businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6000. Maribelle is now borrowing PHP 20,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 8th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 18000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Maribelle aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more product to sell.

loans.name: Purity

texts.en: Purity N. N. is 36 years old, divorced and has two children, aged thirteen and twelve years old. Her electronics business is located at Chaani estate in Mombasa,Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attractions, including the Indian Ocean's white beaches. Purity has been selling items such as music cds, mobile phone accessories and other electrical goods. She has been in this business for four years now and mainly serves the local residents. She says that her business is profitable and the major challenge she has is financial constraints. That said, she works very hard to make sure her business is doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 80,000 to buy more electronics to expand her business. She hopes to be a wholesaler in future and also hopes to give her children a quality education to the university level. She desribes herself as a very hardworking lady.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to sell.

loans.name: Amos

texts.en: Amos is a thirty-five-year-old married man with six children living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda and his family dream is to build his own house. He is a taxi driver and has been in the transport business for twenty years, first as a conductor and now a driver.  His dream is to have at least five taxis. Amos intends to use the loan proceeds to add to what he has to buy a taxi for his transport business.

loans.use: Buying a taxi for transport business

loans.name: Avelino

texts.en:
Avelino C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 60 years old. Avelino is married and has 1 child. He is a rice farmer and supports his family through farming. His wife helps him sell his harvest to the market. Avelino says he wants to improve his earnings so he can keep up with the increasing needs in his household.

Avelino joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Avelino is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure.

loans.name: Benon

texts.en:
Benon is a forty-eight-year-old man, married with ten children, living in Fort Portal, Uganda in his own house. He has been able to support the family of twelve with the help of his wife who is a commercial farmer, and he has a dream of educating his children to higher levels of education. 

Benon has been a professional tailor for the last twenty-eight years and with this business he has been able to educate three of his children until they finished tertiary level. He needs the loan to buy cloth for his tailoring business.

loans.use: Buying cloth for his tailoring business

loans.name: Inocencio

texts.en:
Inocencio Z. is from the village of Brgy. Cutar, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 26 years old and single. To make a living, Inocencio owns and operates a business raising livestock. His main source of income comes primarily from raising pigs for breeding. Inocencio has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. 

Inocencio joined ASKI in 2009 to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase breeding livestock. Inocencio is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Inocencio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated by the loan to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Kalsoom's Group

texts.en:
Kalsoom is a resident of Riwind, a small city in Punjab Pakistan known for its dairy industry. She livesin a 2 room brick house with her family in the area of Jalalpura. 
She is a very skillful person who does sewing and embroidery works for her nearby clients. She receives regular orders and earns good income from her business. 
She is married to R. M., who has a business of selling vegetables. He brings vegetables on a four-wheeled cart every morning and visits different streets of the city to sell them. Kalsoom has given birth to 2 sons. Both of them have left their education after the 8th grade. Her eldest son works in a factory and the youngest one does embroidery works. 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy seasonal vegetables in bulk quantity for selling to his customers. He had done this business for over 15 years and Kalsoom is hopeful that her husband will bring more profits from his business after a loan investment. 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In previous loan year, she has built good credit record and attended every meeting. 
Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Kalsoom.

loans.use: To buy seasonal vegetables for sale

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo C. is from the village of Canicapan Clarin Misamis Occidental. He is 39 years old and married with an infant child. To make a living, Eduardo owns and operates a transportation business. His main source of income comes primarily from providing transportation-based services. Eduardo has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. 

Eduardo joined GDMPC in 2010 to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He  is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP to repair his existing vehicle to provide better service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Eduardo from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Kham

texts.en: Kham K. is 50 years old and a humble villager living in the capital, Phnom Penh, in the middle of Cambodia. He is married and blessed with six children. His wife (pictured) is a farmer who also raises a few pigs behind her house for additional profit. To earn a living, Kham K. distills alcohol. He often receives an order from villagers who lives next and around his house when they need alcohol for celebrating wedding parties or ceremonies. Kham K. is concerned that he is hardly ever able to travel anywhere except by walking. Kham K. dreams of having a vehicle but he doesn’t have money to buy one. Therefore, Kham K. is requesting a loan to purchase a new motorcycle for his traveling.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle for traveling.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en: Sandra is a twenty-seven-year-old woman, married to a driver with two children below ten years of age, living in Fort Portal, Uganda in her own house. She has a dream of educating her children and ensuring that they get better qualifications to earn them reputable jobs. She had a retail shop before turning it into a clothing shop over the past three years, and it has reaped enormous benefits for her. Sandra needs the loan to purchase clothing for sale.

loans.use: Purchasing clothing for sale at her shop

loans.name: Edlen

texts.en:
Edlen B. is from the village of Bayo, Iguig, Cagayan. She is 28 years old. Edlen is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Edlen owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Edlen has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells one of her raised animals.

In 2010, Edlen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edlen is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Edlen from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

To make a living, Rizalina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting coconut for sale. Rizalina has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Rizalina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rizalina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. Rizalina is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 26th loan taken out by Rizalina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Jinna's Group

texts.en:
Jinna is a talented lady who lives in the city of Riwind in Pakistan. She operates a sweater knitting business, which she does at her home to financially support her family. She learned this skill from her mother and is now taking advantage of those skills in the shape of money. She sells her sweaters to different garment shops and earns well on each sale. Her income allows her to pay for the utilities.

She started doing this business after the death of her husband. In the beginning she faced financial problems, but now her business has settled down well and provides her with a regular income every month. She also operates a small grocery shop in her home to increase the household income. She is the mother of 5 sons. None of them could complete their education. Her 3 elder sons work in the factories while the others stay at home and help her in managing the grocery store business.

Jinna has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for her sweater knitting business. With the loan, she will buy thread in larger quantity that will help her knit more sweaters and fulfill larger orders on time. She is hopeful that an investment will be profitable for her business and increase her household income.

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fifth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and paid her installments on time. This is a group loan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Jinna.

loans.use: To buy thread for sweater knitting business.

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda M. is thirty-eight years old and married. Her husband is a fishmonger and they have three children aged between twelve and six years old. Her business is located at Khayega in Kakamega. Kakamega is in the western region of Kenya and is well known for its sugar cane production and as the sugar belt region.

She sells groceries, a business she has done for fourteen years now, and has two employees. Her major customers are local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is when the business goes down because of lack of rain, since in this area the farmers depend on rain to grow crops. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 80,000 to buy more vegetables to boost her business. She hopes to grow her business and diversify to a taxi business. She describes herself as a focussed and determined lady.

loans.use: To buy vegetables.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma G. is a 56 year old widow who supports her family by operating 3 business ventures: sari-sari (general) store, food vending, and farming. She lives in Talusan, Brgy Bulanon, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1996 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her sari-sari (general) store, food vending, and farming businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000.

Norma is now borrowing PHP 29,500 to use as additional funds for business operations. This will be her 19th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Norma aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Funds for business operations.

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Long S., 59 years old, is a rice and vegetable grower from Phnom Penh, the capital. Long S. is a widowed mother blessed with five children. Three of them are now married and the other two are single, and they all are employed at different occupations. She runs her business on her own farmland where she grows different kinds of crops like cabbage, rice, and potatoes, which she sells to a buyer when they have matured. She now earns an average of US$1.00 a day and has been running the business for years.

Currently, her crops are not growing well because they need more fertilizer. To remedy the situation, she would like a loan to buy two sacks of fertilizer for her crops to grow well.

loans.use: To buy two sacks of fertilizer for her crops to grow well.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma T. is a married woman who lives in Purok Kalubihan, Brgy Bulanon, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: a general store and vegetable vending. Her husband, Jessie T., who is 59 years old, works as a driver to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 5 children who are between 15 to 31 years old.

Norma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1996 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Norma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Norma T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

Alfredo has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Alfredo has successfully repaid a previous loan  from GDMPC. Alfredo is requesting a new loan of 19,700 PHP, which will be used to repair his existing vehicle to provide better service. This loan will be the eleventh loan taken out by Alfredo from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Bushra's Group

texts.en:
Bushra lives in Riawind, which is a small city located in Pakistan and famous for its dairy industry. She lives there with her family in an area called Jalalpura, in a 2 room brick house. She moved there after her marriage 17 years ago.

She is a working lady, who does embroidery works to bear the financial burden with her husband. Her husband is a rickshaw driver. He provides transportation services to his passengers and earns income for the family. Bushra is the mother of 5 children. All of them are illiterate as Bushra couldn’t provide them with education due to poor financial conditions.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the growth of her embroidery business. With the loan, she will buy embroidery material such as beads, colored thread, and clothes in bulk that will allow her to fulfill larger orders for her customers on time and to increase her household income as well. 

She has more than 15 years of experience in her business and is hopeful that an investment will bring a lot of positive changes in her business.

This is a group loan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Bushra.

loans.use: To buy embroidery material for embroidery business.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda Nidar F. is a married woman who lives in Purok Croton's A, Brgy Old Sagay, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a fishing/fish vending business. Her husband Antonio F., who is 39 years old, works as selling fish to earn his living. They have 2 children who are 10 and 12 years old.

Rosalinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1995 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosalinda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 16th loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to purchase a fishing boat so that she can continue to save up for future business improvements. Rosalinda Nidar F. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Sang

texts.en:
Sang J. is 27 years old and has been in the farming business for four years. He is married and has two children, aged 3 years and 2 months, respectively.His milk produce is sold locally.

He has requested for this loan of 60,000KES from Juhudi Kilimo, he intends to purchase a dairy cow to be able to sell more milk. With increased income from his business, he hopes to help his family by paying school fees for his child of school-going age.His additional income is from teaching salary.

Sang's challenge remain poor market prices for the milk and animal diseases.He hopes that Juhudi Kilimo continues with the good work it is doing.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase yarns, cloths and threads to be used in the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Erlinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

texts.en:

loans.name: Umoja Development Group-Jinja

texts.en: Francis O., 44 years old, belongs to the Umoja Development group-Jinja. For the last 5 years, Francis has been bringing hard work to bear in his poultry sales business in Jinja Metropolis. He says he began this business after retirement from his past job in a steel rolling company. Francis is happily married with 8 kids. He makes a monthly profit of 300,000 UGX. With this loan that he is requesting, he says he is going to buy more chickens and bags of millet. Additional proceeds will go towards paying fees for his kids.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens and bags of millet

loans.name: Mwanaache

texts.en:
Mwanaache is a widowed woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees, food and hospital bills.

For over five years, she has operated a weaving business selling house mats, hats and clothes to tourists visiting her area of operation. Mwanaache faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the months of April and May, few tourists visit the country, hence less income, while during the months of November and December, the season is high because of the high number of tourists visiting the country, hence high numbers of customers which increases her income. She hopes to establish a grocery shop and open a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase weaving materials for weaving baskets, hats and clothes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to start a business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for weaving baskets, hats and clothes for sale.
