loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol N. is from the village of Alimannao, Peñablanca, Cagayan. She is 33 years old. Mirasol is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Mirasol owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. Mirasol has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 5,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Mirasol joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mirasol has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Mirasol is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Mirasol from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina M. K. is thirty-five years old, married, and has five children aged between fourteen and two years old. Her business is located at Mariakani estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian ocean white beaches.

She provides tailoring services to the local people. She also makes clothes and displays them for sale to her customers. She has been in this business for fifteen years now and has three employees. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is tied-up capital since some customers order clothes to be made and then refuse to pick up the clothes, and so she has to put them on display for other people to buy them later. This, she says, slows her business. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well.

She is using her loan of Kes 40,000 to buy materials to expand her business. She hopes to grow her business and even start selling materials to other tailors. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy materials.

loans.name: Burulcha's Group

texts.en:
One might think that a country that exports food supplies in large quantities has plenty of products for local consumers. That is not true for Kyrgyzstan. The most necessary food supplies like meat, fruits, and milk products are a luxury for a typical rural family. The government regulations fail to efficiently allocate locally-made products, while most of it goes for cheap export. Local citizens purchase goods at quite a high price.

Burulcha N., 53, is a leader of this group. She is a junior nurse in a sanitary-epidemic hospital in the small town of Toktogul. She is a widow and has four grown children. She worked hard her entire career in a hospital but still could not provide a good life with the salary of a social worker. She did a tremendous job in satisfying all the needs of her children, and now it is her children’s turn to bring some fresh air into their mother’s life. 

Burulcha’s youngest son spent his salary to purchase cattle. Together, they managed to gradually increase the number of cattle. The biggest challenge for this family is to find capital for conducting business, because the input prices rise every year and sometimes it gets hard to cover production costs. Burulcha has organized a group of people, each of whom has unique financial hardships. Burulcha is asking for a loan of 10,000 soms so that she can buy additional cattle and make general repairs on her house. 

 --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma F. is from the village of Poblacion 2 Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 60 years old and married with two adult children. To make a living, Thelma owns a business planting and harvesting lanzones, a tropical fruit, for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Thelma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from GDMPC and is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Thelma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Leonisa

texts.en:
Leonisa D. is from the village of Malibangcao Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Leonisa cooks and sells food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Leonisa has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Leonisa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Leonisa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be Leonisa's ninth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherpeople, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Josephine Muthamba

texts.en:
Josephine is 34 years old, married to Benson, and they have three children. They also support two other relatives from the extended family. Josephine normally works on their family farm. She sells the produce to her neighbors and other vegetable traders. She and her husband have been in the farming business for two years now, with an income of 5,000 KES a month.

Josephine is borrowing her second loan with KADET to buy water pipes for pumping water to their farm. She hopes to produce better quality cabbages to distribute on a large scale in this current season.

loans.use: To buy water pipes for watering the farm

loans.name: Namizzi Central Group - Jinja

texts.en:
For the last 9 and a half years, 42-year-old M. Asuman has been operating a farm supplies business in Buyala trading center in Jinja. He has mostly been selling veterinary medicines. He began this business after he finished apprentice training courtesy of his uncle. Before that he was more into agro produce sales. 

Asuman is a married man with eight kids, six of whom go to school. He says only hard work, courage and prayers have gotten him this far. This business generates 100,000 shillings weekly for him. With this loan, he is going to buy more veterinary medicines to supply his old and new clients.

loans.use: To purchase more veterinary medicines

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn L. is from the village of Segatic daku Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years old, married and has five adult children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a transportation services business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a transportation service. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Jocelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to repair her vehicle for better service. This loan will be Jocelyn's seventh loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmer, fisherpeople, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Raquel's Group

texts.en:
Raquel B. is from the village of Culalabat, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 22 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. Raquel is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

To make a living, Raquel raises livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Raquel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP every four months.

In 2009, Raquel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Raquel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. The previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Raquel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This loan will be Raquel's fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherpeople, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Shamshad's Group

texts.en:
Shamshad lives in Khanewal, a small city in Pakistan known for its agriculture industry. She lives there with her family in a two-room brick house in an area called Railway landy. She moved there 15 years ago. She is a housewife and spends most of her time at home doing her housework. She is a mother of three sons and two daughters. All of them are getting their education except the eldest, who works in a factory.

She is married to S. M. who works for Pakistan Railways. He also runs an animal sales business. He buys animals at cheap rates from the animal markets, raises them, and sells them to customers. 

Shamshad has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan he will buy some goats, raise them, and then sell them to his customers for a good profit. He has been involved in this business for the past 10 years and Shamshad is very confident that her husband will make good money from his business after the loan investment. She is a regular user of the Asasah loan service and this is her fifth loan application.  

Note: In the photo, the lady who holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Shamshad.

loans.use: To buy goats for animal sales business

loans.name: Gulvarkhon's Group

texts.en:
Kyrgyzstan is slowly developing its fashion industry. Such clothing designers as Dilbar Ashimbaeva, Assol Moldokmatova and Galina Boikova are proving that Kyrgyz ornaments and traditional accessories can arouse a great deal of interest on an international scale.

Gulvarkhon J., the 48-year-old leader of this group, is a resident of Uzgen and the mother of eight daughters, three of whom are under 18. Her husband is a cab driver. A unique designer and sewer, Gulvarkhon's creation is a “tushak”, which is a mattress or a blanket that is usually spread on the floor with pillows on it. It’s a great symbol of Kyrgyz handmade traditional goods, and almost every family has some at home, which explains the big demand for them. Gulvarkhon used to make tushaks just for home use or as gifts to friends, but one day her friend suggested that it could be a good business idea. And she was right. The popularity of these tushaks has spurred great interest among both local residents and foreigners.

Sewing these tushaks requires large expenditures on inputs such as fabrics of cotton, velvet and velor. Gulvarkon believes that her group is suitable for this loan and she thanks all lenders. Gulvarkhon’s dream is to purchase a two-storied house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials for sewing

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a 37-year-old woman, married to Harrison Muya. She has two businesses: selling shoes and jackets is her primary business and she has a grocery store as a secondary business. She has been in these businesses for 10 years and earns 6,000 Kenyan shillings per month. She normally supplies nearby hotels with vegetables from her green grocery business, but also has a space in the market where she sells shoes and jackets.

Agnes has applied for a loan which she intends to use to increase her stock of tomatoes and jackets. She hopes to run a more stable business and increase her stock so that she can supply big hotels in Nairobi.

loans.use: To increase stock for a grocery store

loans.name: Said

texts.en:
Said is a single man who owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food and clothing.

He has operated his boutique business for the past six years, selling at the market to his neighbours and passersby. Said faces a major challenge of seasonality. During holiday season, the demand for clothes is high compared to when schools have opened, the demand for clothes is low. He hopes to expand and become a big supplier of clothes to other boutiques in the future.

With the Kshs 60,000, he wants to purchase a bale of clothes for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve his standards of living.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of clothes for resale

loans.name: Maria Linda

texts.en:
Maria Linda M. is from the city of Pallua Sur, Tuguegarao City. She is 38 years old. Maria Linda is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Maria Linda owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maria Linda has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Maria Linda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Linda has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Maria Linda is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Maria Linda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of the borrower's children.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is a housewife, stays at home and does her household work. She is a very active and supportive lady who has been living in the city of Khanewal since her marriage with K. 21 years ago. Khanewal is a small city in Punjab province known for its agriculture industry. She lives there in a two-room brick house with her family.

Her husband works in Pakistan railways and also has a part-time business of tailoring. His shop is in the market and earns him good income. He specifically sews gents clothes and is very famous among his customers due to his quality work. She is the mother of two sons and a daughter. Her elder son is also a tailor while her daughter is studying in eighth class.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business of tailoring. With the loan, he will buy another sewing machine and also hire a worker who will assist him in his work and in completing the work on time.

EID season is near and Nasreen is hopeful that during this season, her husband will get a large number of orders and an additional sewing machine will help him do his business more efficiently and in completing the orders as well.

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting

loans.use: To buy another sewing machine for tailoring business

loans.name: Gulya's Group

texts.en:
It’s a great felicity to become parents. Kyrgyz value family ties a lot and usually have very big families. Taking care of your family members and helping out in different situations is a very important part of Kyrgyz traditions. However, raising children becomes quite a challenge financially. Parents do their best to lead children away to a worthy future.

Gulya N., 37, is a treasurer of this group. Gulya and her husband always loved children and dreamed about having a big friendly family. Fortunately, they were blessed to become parents of three wonderful boys and a girl. All of them are under 18 years old. Gulya and her husband truly believe that their children will find a right path in life. The father of the family works as a driver in a local construction firm “Kurulush”, but he realized that unfortunately, his salary is not enough to provide his children with a good college education. So Gulya decided to make her own contribution in a family budget. For her husband’s monthly salary, she purchased two cattle. Soon she managed to gain profit for buying an additional one. At this moment, she runs her business successfully and would like to get a loan to purchase one more cattle. With proceeds of business, she plans to buy a bigger amount of cattle and to purchase a piece of land for constructing a house of her dream. Gulya already is running this business for four years and she’s 100 percent sure that the demand for her product will increase.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean L. is from the village of Alimannao, Peñablanca, Cagayan. She is 29 years old. Jean is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Jean owns and operates a specialized store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling AVON products such as lotion, deodorant and perfumes in the local community. Jean has been engaged in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Jean joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Jean from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Caxton

texts.en:
Caxton is a single gentleman, age 20 years old. He is a businessman who has been selling secondhand clothes for the past year. He normally earns a monthly income of 4,500 Kenyan shillings. He uses his income to support two of his family members.

Caxton has never borrowed from any microfinance institution (MFI). He was introduced to KADET by one of the credit officers. He is applying for his first loan and plans to add clothes stock and purchase livestock. He anticipates some profit which he intends to save for the future when he gets married and has children to educate. His dreams are to start another business and save money for the betterment of his future family.

loans.use: To add clothes stock and purchase livestock

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina T. is 46 years old, single and has one grown son. She lives in Sokuluk village in the northern part of Kyrgyzstan. Irina began her business in cattle breeding in 2005 in order to find an additional means of subsistence. With her initial capital of 6,000 KGS, Irina bought a bull. Today, she manages to earn about 5,000 KGS per month by selling meat products.
Irina is applying for a loan of 80,000 KGS to purchase bull calves for fattening and resale. In the future, she plans to broaden her business by purchasing more cattle.

About Bai-Tushum and Partners
Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Elias

texts.en:
Elias is a forty-six-year-old married man with six children and charged with the responsibility of looking after the family, living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has an ambitious goal of ensuring that his family gets all their basic needs and have an income-generating activity for each child.

Elias owns a shop and has a retailing experience of ten years from which he has been able to educate some of his children and also buy land. His intention for this loan is to enable him to purchase sugar, salt, cooking oil, and soap to sell.

loans.use: Purchasing sugar, salt, cooking oil, and soap to sell for a profit

loans.name: Bilqees Sardar Masih's Group

texts.en:
Bilqees lives in a three-roomed brick house with her family in the area of Railway landy, a railway housing scheme in Khanewal. Khanewal is a small city located in Punjab province, Pakistan, and known for its agricultural industry.
Bilqees is a housewife as well as a working woman. To support her family financially, she operates a business selling shawls. She buys them from Multan (famous for its clothes) and sells them to customers in her local area. Her customers include clothes shop owners and people from her neighborhood.
Bilqees' husband is a government employee on a meager income and her only son works in a factory. Her sons left education after 5th grade due to poor financial conditions and the commencement of his factory work.
Bilqees has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her shawl business. With the loan, she will buy shawls of different kinds (such as simple, colored and embroidered) in large quantities because the winter season is near and demand for shawls will become high. She is hopeful that her business will have a bright future and that investment will do her business a lot of good. Bilqees is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous years, she has maintained good credit behavior and has never missed a meeting.
Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (the Asasah Passbook) is Bilqees.

loans.use: To buy shawls for resale

loans.name: Swalehe

texts.en:
Swalehe is a married man with six children, three of whom attend school while the other three are still too young to go to school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food.
Swalehe operates a retail shop, selling wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, rice and cooking oil. His potential customers are neighbors and passers-by. Swalehe faces the major challenge of seasonality and high transport costs incurred while transporting goods from the market to his place of operation. He hopes to sells his goods wholesale in the future.
With this loan of 40,000 KES he wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, sugar, rice and cooking oil. He decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of maize flour, sugar, rice and cooking oil

loans.name: Katcha Mamaeva's Group

texts.en:
The partnership of microfinance organizations with Kiva brings change into the lives of thousands of families who are less fortunate in life. It’s amazing how people from different parts of the planet care about the lives of people they haven’t even met. The basic foundation of a project like Kiva is the hearts of those people – who are not indifferent and can help in a challenging situation in life.
Katcha M., 53, is the leader of this group. She lives in the small town of Uzgen, in the south of Kyrgyzstan. The majority of the town's population is engaged in farming. The most popular and unique crop here is a certain type of brown rice.
Katcha confesses that the greatest accomplishment in her life was bringing up seven noble children. Her oldest child is 33 years old and the youngest is 16. For this family, farming has been the only source of income for the last 27 years. Their business story started when Katcha bought a cow with a calf for 6,500 KGS. Every member did what they could to push forward dairy production. At first, the dairy assortment was very narrow, but now the diversification of products is impressive. The family supplies milk, butter and sour cream.
Katcha is excited to be taking her first loan with Kiva partner, Mol Bulak, after realizing how many great opportunities this loan will give her. She can’t wait until she gets this loan to expand her business, enabling her to be a better provider for her family. Milk products have a great quality and are in high demand. With the proceeds from her loan, Katcha will organize a long-awaited wedding ceremony for her son.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy wood and nails

loans.name: Vol

texts.en:
Vol H. is 52 years old and married with seven children. She lives in the Takeo province. She makes and sells cakes in her village and is able to make about 1 USD in daily profit. Her husband, pictured here, is a bicycle repairer. On average, he earns 3 USD a day. Three of the couple’s children are working in construction to help support their family.

Daily transportation is expensive for the family, so Vol H. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase a motorbike. She hopes a new motorbike will reduce her family’s transportation expenditures.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Kalsoom Younas Farooq Group

texts.en:
Kalsoom lives in a small city of Punjab province of Pakistan called Khanewal that is famous for its agriculture industry. She lives in a two-room brick house in an area named Railway Landy, with her husband and their 17-year-old son. Kalsoom moved to her house after her marriage to Y. F., who has a barber shop business. Kalsoom’s son left school after fifth grade. Now he stays at home, and Kalsoom prays that he will find suitable work soon and start contributing financially to the family. 

Kalsoom is a housewife who works in the home. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her husband expand his barber shop business. With the loan, he will buy necessary items such as scissors, hair shampoo, and hair gels to offer better services to his customers. Kalsoom is hopeful that her husband, who started this business 5 years ago, will be able to improve his business with the help of this loan.  

Kalsoom is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fifth loan application. She has maintained a good credit repayment history and never misses meetings. In this photo, Kalsoom is seen holding her passbook, the Asasah Passbook.

loans.use: to buy items for barber shop business

loans.name: Phouk

texts.en:
Phouk L. is 56 years old and raises pigs in the village of Takeo province. She has been raising pigs since 2000, and is able to make about 2 USD in daily profit. Her husband is a musician who, on average, makes a daily profit of 2 USD as well. Phouk L.'s husband makes his highest earnings during the wedding season, which is November through May. 

Phouk L. is asking for a loan of 500 USD to purchase a motorbike

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Marjan's Group

texts.en:
What is aging? Some people treat it with respect as a sign of wisdom and greatness. Some fear it, and try to face it as late as possible. And some just accept it as inevitable human nature and deal with it easily. Our next heroine thinks that aging is not an excuse for not following dreams and being successful.
 
Marjan D., 63, born in the small town of Toktogul, started her business breeding livestock 25 years ago. Growing up in the village, this was the only thing she spent her whole time on and was good at. The art of taking good care of livestock is carefully taught from one generation to the next. Marjan is married and is fortunate to have five children. Her husband has worked as a surgeon his entire life. The children are already grown and have their own families. Marjan used only 15,000 KGS for her business start-up and had to sacrifice her husband’s salary. She and her husband understood that it was very risky to invest the last savings in business start-up, but an endless hope and belief drove them forward. Despite her age, Marjan is a very ambitious woman. She gathered a group of four businessmen who are very experienced in breeding livestock before she applied for a loan. At this time Marjan needs 20,000 KGS, which she will use to purchase one more head of cattle. Her dream is to purchase land in the capital Bishkek.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Yin

texts.en: Yin N., 31, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province. Since 2009, she has been making and selling rice noodles. She is able to make about 2 USD of profit every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a moto-taxi driver. On average, he makes 3 USD per day. This couple has three children; one is employed and two are in school. Yin N. is asking for a loan of 1000 USD to reinvest in her business. She will also use a portion of the loan to finish construction.

loans.use: Invest in rice noodle business and finish construction

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret is a thirty-five-year-old lady, hard-working, married with four children living together in her own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her family dream is to improve  her household income and have her children educated as well. She deals in selling clothes and has been doing this business for the last ten years now, however she still faces a challenge of limited capital to meet   the high demand of her customers. Margret is in need of the loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Paying school fees for her children.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem R. is 43 years old and raises pigs in a village in Takeo province. She has been raising pigs since 2002 and is able to make about 2 USD of profit every day. Her husband, pictured here, works in construction. On average, he makes 3 USD of profit a day as well. Sem R. is asking for a loan of 1000 USD to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita is married with two grown children and an 8-year-old daughter. She is a small business owner from Vinogradovo, Western Ukraine. Margarita sells men’s outer wear, lamps and chandeliers in the central marketplace of her home town. Her vending facility is located right in the centre of the market. There are few competitors with the same stock for sale which creates favorable conditions for the growth of Margarita’s business.  

Margarita has been in this sphere of trade for 10 years. Presently, she has 30,000 Grivnyas in turnover capital. Her gross income amounts to 12,000 Grivnyas. Monthly net profit is 3,000 Grivnyas. Margarita is requesting a loan of 7,000 Grivnyas to invest in increasing her working capital. She is hoping to add items to the selection of inventory she offers for sale in her kiosk. Margarita is an ambitious entrepreneur. She doesn’t want to stop where she is at. She is hoping to open an additional vending location in the nearest future thus expanding her business even further.

loans.use: to increase her working capital

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s sweetmeat-selling business. With the loan, her husband will buy necessary items such as sugar, milk, and dried fruits in larger quantity that will help him to make larger quantities of sweetmeats to meet the demand of his customers and to expand his business. 

She lives in Khanewal which is a small city located in Punjab province, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She lives there in a single-room brick house with her family in the area called Railway Landy. She moved here after her marriage to A. A. 14 years ago. She has given birth to 2 daughters and 2 sons. Her daughters are studying while her sons are too young to attend school. 

She herself is a housewife and stays at home, doing her household work and taking care of her children. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application.  She is hopeful that this loan investment will be a profitable one for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy necessary items for sweetmeat-selling business

loans.name: Tim

texts.en: Tim S. is 37 years old and sells vegetables in the market of her Takeo province. Her business has been around for about four years and she makes US$ 4 every day. Her husband grows rice and watermelon. On average, he earns US$ 2 in profit a day. This couple has three children. Tim S. wants to take out a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase cows to plow their farmland.

loans.use: To purchase cows to plow their farmland

loans.name: Yuryi

texts.en:
Yuryi is married with two young children. He is a small businessman from Vinogradovo. Yuryi offers transportation services. He launched this enterprise 8 years ago. He purchased a car for 40,000 Grivnyas and started working as a taxi driver. Ever since then, his pricing policy has remained reasonable and affordable thus attracting a number of clients. Currently, Yuryi makes about 8,000 Grivnyas a month. His profit amounts to 4,000 Grivnyas.   

Yuryi is seeking a 10,000 Grivnya loan to receive his vehicle service record and do major repairs on his vehicle. He enjoys owning his business and believes he could never exchange being self-employed for any other job. One of Yuryi’s future plans is to put aside enough savings to be able to afford buying a newer car.

loans.use: to do major repairs on his vehicle

loans.name: Orozbu's Group

texts.en:
Unfortunately women in Kyrgyzstan, especially in rural areas, have a very narrow choice of work. If a foreigner goes to local bazaars, he would think that only women live in this region. The very few things they can do are retail, farming, stock-breeding and nursing. Considering past mistakes, many families try to give their children a good education. 

Orozbu K., 50, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of a small town, Uzgen. She’s a single mother of two sons in their twenties. Just like thousands of young guys throughout the country, her second son, finding no job opportunities in Kyrgyzstan, decided to leave for Russia and make his living there. Her oldest son is a cab driver, and drives for almost twelve hours a day on a major route of the country, which connects the only two developed cities. 

Both of Orozbu’s sons invest a part of their savings in a family business, which was started in 1998. Her main occupation has been retailing food supplies, including rice, sugar, and pasta. In summertime she switches to the sale of watermelons, which have a huge supply in summer, especially in southern Kyrgyzstan. Orozbu is excited to get this loan of 10,000 soms, money that will be spent on circulation of commodities. Orozbu and her group are very thankful to all lenders and believe they will repay the loan successfully. 

 --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase products for sale

loans.name: Saida

texts.ru: Сайидмуродова Саида проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 45 лет. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Муж имеет хлебопекарню, где печет хлеб (лепешка). Сама Саида занимается торговлей на рынке "Дехкон". Она арендует торговую точку, где продает национальный хлеб (лепешка). Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 10 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Saida S. lives in Tursunzoda. She is 45 years old, married with two children. Her husband owns a bakery where he bakes traditional "Lepyoshka" bread. Saida rents out a trading spot at the local "Dakhkon" market where she has sold "Lepyoshkas" for over 10 years. She is applying for a loan to increase sales.

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a married woman with seven children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees.

She has operated a retail shop for over three years, selling to her neighbors and people who pass by her store. A major challenge Mwanasiti faces is the seasonality of her business. She hopes to sell wholesale products in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase two sacks of sugar, wheat flour, maize flour and washing soaps. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to start her business.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks of sugar, wheat flour, maize flour and washing soaps.

loans.name: Jumakul's Group

texts.en:
Jumakul, second from right, is a woman of 59 who is married and has three grown, self-sufficient sons. Five years ago the family started their own cattle-raising business. Additionally, Jumakul adds to the family income by working as a watchman for a private organization. Her husband is a pensioner who entirely devotes himself to farming. In order to build a house, the family intends to increase their earnings by purchasing more cattle to fatten and sell. A loan will make this plan come true.

	--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team — Supporters of Kyrgyzstan — Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Nyabugando Farmers Association-Rukungiri Group

texts.en: Cledonia M. is 31 years old and married with three children. She belongs to the Nyabugando Farmers Group-Rukungiri. She has been operating an agricultural business in Kitazigurukaha for two years. Cledonia began her business after completing training from the national agricultural advisory services. She will use her loan to improve her poultry farm.

loans.use: to improve poultry farm

loans.name: Elias Comba

texts.en:
Elias is 30 years old and married to Stella. They have two children. Elias has been the farming business for six years and earns a monthly income of 10,000 KES. 

This will be his third loan with KADET. Elias has never borrowed from another microfinance institution before. He wants to use this loan to buy fertilizers and chemicals for his crops. Elias hopes to build a permanent house to live with his family on land he has bought.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Reteti Ole

texts.en:
Reteti Ole K. is 24 years old, married to Hellen Ikayo and the father of three children who attend school. Reteti is a businessman who buys and sells livestock. He has been doing this kind of business for the past four years. 
  
He learned about KADET from a neighbor who was already a KADET client. This will be Reteti’s second loan. He is requesting a loan of 80,000 KES to purchase livestock and expand his shed to improve his business. Reteti plans to purchase a plot of land for his family with the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan. 

Reteti is a hardworking man and will do well with the right resources. His hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer in the livestock selling business.

loans.use: to buy livestock and expand livestock shed

loans.name: Mehnaz's Group

texts.en: Mehnaz is from the city of Lahore, in Pakistan. Lahore is the second largest city of Pakistan and known for its culture and history. She is a housewife who stays at home and takes care of her household. She is not able to support her husband financially by working but always trys to help him improve his business any way she can. That’s why she has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s spare parts business, which supports the family. With the loan, he will buy spare parts in larger quantities to meet the urgent orders of his customers. Mehnaz hopes that by investing the loan money into her husband’s business, he will make more income and improve his business conditions.

loans.use: To buy parts for a spare parts business

loans.name: Gulbaram's Group

texts.en:
Gulbaram is a woman of 47, married to a farming association member. The couple raised three grown children, although two daughters still live with their parents; their elder brother is married and works to support his own family. Since 1999, the family has had a small trading business selling fruit and vegetables. In order to increase sales, Gulbaram has managed to build a real shop. Now she hopes to obtain a loan to develop her business further and increase the family income. In future Gulbaram plans to improve her living conditions.   

	--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: People (building human capital and taking care of customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more fruit and vegetables for sale

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a 31-year-old man, married to an enterprising wife, who is a hairdresser, and blessed with three children below the age of 10. They live in Fort Portal, Uganda. Stephen is a motorcycle driver. He has been in the transport sector for four years now, since he branched out from the agricultural sector. He is proud of the way his venture is faring, although he has the challenge of irregular customers due to seasonal changes. Stephen needs this loan to buy a motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for a transport business

loans.name: Stephen Ng'ang'a

texts.en:
Stephen is married to Salome and the father of two children who are two and ten years old. For the past four years, he has been operating a barber shop in Limuru town which is on the outskirts of Nairobi. Limuru is a relatively busy business location with a high population that is favorable for Stephen’s shop. 

Stephen got to know about KADET through a friend who was already a member. Stephen has not borrowed from other financiers before. He has applied for his first loan to buy building materials to build his own business premises instead of paying rent which is very costly.

Stephen’s desire is to give his children a better education and a better life.

loans.use: to buy building materials

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is a 31-year-old married man with two children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. His family dream is ensuring that his household becomes a model home in the area. He distills alcohol for a living and has been in the business for seven years now. He is proud to have been able to buy land from his savings. Robert intends to invest his loan in buying high quality equipment for distilling local brew to sell.

loans.use: To buy high quality equipment for distilling local brew

loans.name: Haydar

texts.ru: Назаров Хайдар проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 28 лет. Женат, имеет одного ребенка. Образование высшее, экономист. По профессии не работает. Занимается торговлей в торговом центре "Гулчахон". Он в основном продает DVD диски. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 5 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: N. Haydar lives in the city of Kulob. He's twenty-eight years old, married and has one child. He has a degree in economics and has worked as a salesman for five years. Currently, he sells DVD disks at the Gulchahon shopping center. He's asking for a loan to increase his goods turnover.

loans.use: to increase his sales.

loans.name: Odonchimeg

texts.en: Odonchimeg D. is 44 years old and lives with her husband and three children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her oldest son and daughter both attend university and her youngest son attends a local high school. Her husband works as a driver in the Erel company. She opened a small shop in 2004 and has since expanded it by selling more variety of grocery products. After years of successful operation, Odonchimeg hopes to establish a supermarket. Her earnings have enabled her to provide for her family. She is a very hard-working person who wants to keep growing her business. She says, "I want to make my business a stable operation and build a house with three floors for my family." She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy more products for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products

loans.name: Ihembe Tukwatanise Group, Kihihi

texts.en: T. Norah, with hand raised, is the leader of Ihembe Tukwatanise loan group. She is 68 years old and a widow with four children. Norah has been involved in the buying and selling of food crops in Ihembe for 28 years and makes KES90,000 profit per week. Her repeat customers are good people.  She started her business using money from her own harvests but now needs a loan to increase her working capital. She is very hard working and dreams about improving her home. In the absence of her late husband, she is grateful for the loans that have made it easier for her to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Increase her capital and buy more produce to sell.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon M., aged 25, is a single businessman. He runs a general shop in Tala where he sells flour, sugar, cooking fat, and hair pieces among other items. His customers come from Tala and its surroundings.  He has been running this business for three years and makes a monthly profit of Kshs 15,000. Simon was introduced to KADET LTD by the credit officer in charge of the Tala office. He has applied for a loan to increase his inventory. If the loan succeeds in boosting business, Simon plans to expand his shop to wholesale. Simon describes himself as hard-working and dreams of having a wholesale business, getting married, and being able to provide for a family.

loans.use: To buy stocks of sugar, cooking fat, and maize and wheat flour.

loans.name: Peninah

texts.en: Peninah is a 36 year-old business lady. She is married to M. a farmer and they have two children. Peninah has been operating a green grocery business for the past two years. Her monthly income is Kes 8,000, which she uses to support four members of her family. Peninah has previously never borrowed from any MFI (Microfinance Institution) and she was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our Credit Officers. She is applying for her first loan with which to add to her stock of tomatoes and green vegetables. She wants the profit from her business to pay school fees for her children and improve her family diet. Her future hopes are to expand her business, improve her family's living standard, and educate her children.

loans.use: To add to her vegetable stock

loans.name: Beth

texts.en: Beth W. is 38 years old and married to Reuben Maina. They have four children. She has been farming for 10 years and earns an income of Kshs 9,000 per month. Beth has a good history with KADET, and is applying for her fourth loan after having repaid back her previous loans successfully. She intends to use the loan to buy another dairy cow to increase her milk production. She hopes to improve the living standard of her family and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy another cow.

loans.name: Fredrick Gitau

texts.en:
Fredrick is a 51 year-old farmer, married to Jane (shown here). They have three children. Fredrick has run a quarry business for the past nine years and also raises pigs as a secondary business. His monthly income is Kshs 8,000.

Fredrick has never borrowed from any MFI (microfinance institution) before and was introduced to KADET LTD through a Kadet credit officer. He has applied for his first loan to purchase quarry tools like a mallet, hammer, and wheelbarrow as well as piglet feed. With the anticipated profit from the business he intends to start poultry farming.

Fredrick's hope is to see his family stable, and educate his children so they can achieve their dreams and goals in life.

loans.use: To buy piglet feed and quarry tools.

loans.name: Isa

texts.en: Isa A. is 48 years old and lives with his wife and four children and daughter-in-law in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent. Two of his children, aged 19 and 23, are university students while the other children stay at home. Isa operates a retail clothing business from a rented stall at the local market. He began his business in 2004 selling small accessories. Since then, he has been able to start a retail clothing stall. In addition, his sister has helped to sell his products in the Russian market. He usually imports his clothing items from China and keeps an inventory of between 4,000,000 and 5,000,000 MNT. After many years he has built a successful operation and his monthly sales have reached a level of 1,500,000 to 2,000,000 MNT, with 25-35% considered net profit. For the future, he wants to be able to pay for his children to go to university and get a good education. Isa is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to import more clothing for his retail stall.

loans.use: To import more clothing

loans.name: Mutunga

texts.en:
Mutunga K. is a 34-year-old businessman who sells charcoal at the Nairobi Tena estate. Tena is a well-populated medium class estate with most people using charcoal for cooking, so Mutunga’s customers are many. He is married to Catherine Nzisa and together they have three children, two sons aged 10 and 4 years who go to school and one daughter aged 3 years. He has been running the charcoal business for 10 years and his monthly profit is Kshs 4,000.

Mutunga was introduced to Kadet Ltd by other Kadet customers; previously he received a loan from another micro finance institution called Jamii Bora before joining Kadet Ltd. This will be his second loan from Kadet with which he will buy more sacks of charcoal to increase his stock. If the loan boosts the business, Mutunga will open another charcoal outlet in the neighborhood.

With promising future prospects, Mutunga dreams of becoming a big charcoal distributor who will buy a car for transporting his charcoal and be able to educate his children to high levels. He describes himself as honest and hardworking.

loans.use: To increase his stock of charcoal

loans.name: Nankayia

texts.en:
Nankayia S., aged 33, sells curios at Bissil Market, which has a good clientele.  Most of her customers are women.  She is married to John Saitoi, a farmer who is 35 years old.  The couple has two daughters, Mary and Joy, who are in school.  Nankayia has been in the curio business for 10 years, and her monthly profit is 4,000 Kenyan shillings (KES).

Nankayia learned about KADET Ltd. through a business-awareness meeting conducted in Bissil market by KADET staff.  This is her first KADET loan, and she plans to use it to buy materials to make curios.  For example, she will buy beads of different types to make items such as necklaces and bangles that she will then sell.  If the loan boosts her business, she plans to open a curio wholesale business at Masai Market.

Nankayia describes herself as a hardworking lady.  In the future, she would like to become a wholesaler of curios.

loans.use: To buy materials to make curios

loans.name: Jargalsaihan

texts.en:
Jargalsaihan R. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and two adult children in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest son attends college while his wife sells a variety of Jargalsaihan’s steel and iron products from a rented stall at the Harhorin, one of the main markets in the city.

Jargalsaihan has been working as an ironsmith in his home since 2004. Before starting his iron craft business, he worked as a bookkeeper for a company in Hovd province in 1978 and an electrician for the Tulga company in 1990. Besides his business earnings, the family has several income sources including his wife's monthly pension of 104,000 MNT and his monthly disability pension of 54,000 MNT.

Jargalsaihan is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to increase his working capital for his ironcraft business. In the future he hopes to expand his business by producing more kinds of products. Jargalsaihan says, "I want to continue grow my business, and buy a plot of land and fence for my son who will live on his own soon."

loans.use: To increase his working capital for his iron craft business

loans.name: Ubaydullo

texts.ru: Косимов Убайдулло проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 35 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Образование среднее. Работает на центральном рынке города. Имеет торговую точку, где продает продукты питания. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 15 лет. Убайдулло хочет улучшить финансовое положение в семье. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: K. Ubaydullo lives in the city of Kulob. He's thirty-five years old, married, has three children and a high school level of education. He's worked as a salesman for fifteen years. Currently, he owns a small shop in the city's central market, where he sells foodstuffs. Ubaydullo wants to improve his families' financial standing and, so, is asking for a loan in order to increase his goods turnover.

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Orozbek

texts.en:
Orozbek J. is a 58-year-old farmer who lives in Kulanak village. He is married and has six children. Orozbek worked as a foreman at the local pump plant for twenty years and now receives a pension. In order to find additional means of subsistence, he decided to develop his farm that has been maintained for more than twenty years.

Orozbek started this business with initial capital of 10,000 KGS and managed to enlarge it by two cows, two sheep and ten goats. Orozbek also broadened the farm by breeding poultry; now he has seventy turkeys and thirty hens. With the revenues from this activity, he was able to buy a car for his family. Conditions are good for breeding livestock, and he plans to purchase more cattle.

Orozbek decided to apply for a loan of 52,000 KGS to buy three bull calves. With the revenue, he wants to hold his son’s wedding and build up a good dowry for his daughter.

About Bai-Tushum and Partners:

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable segment of Kyrgyzstan’s population. It is one of the leading microfinance institutions in the country. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services to rural and urban areas that leads to increased employment and meets the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To buy three bull calves
